items.title: Canadian dollar hits near five-month high despite GDP miss
items.author: Fergal Smith

items.title: Bank of Canada can't tell if next rate move will be a hike or a cut, say minutes
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- The BoC left the policy rate at 2.25% and said it would act again if needed to curb inflation or support a weak economy.
- Minutes cite unpredictable U.S. trade policy and volatile data as key reasons the next move—hike or cut—is uncertain.
- Markets priced in about a 25 bp hike by October 2026, with risks from the USMCA review and data shocks shaping the outlook.

items.title: Trump says anybody that disagrees with him will never be Fed Chair
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- President Trump said the next Federal Reserve chair should lower interest rates if markets are doing well.
- He warned that anyone who disagrees with him would never be appointed Fed Chair.
- The comments raise questions about political influence on central bank decisions and independence.

items.title: Uganda restricts imports of Starlink equipment weeks before election
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Uganda restricts imports of Starlink satellite internet gear ahead of the January 15 election; many devices have already been imported despite no operating license.
- A December memo, confirmed by the Uganda Revenue Authority, requires Starlink imports to be cleared by Muhoozi Kainerugaba, Museveni’s son and military chief.
- Opponents say the move could curb information access during the vote; Uganda faced a nationwide internet shutdown in 2021, fueling censorship concerns.

items.title: South African rand climbs further on gold price
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- The rand traded at 16.6875 per dollar at 0745 GMT, strongest since Aug 2022, helped by gold prices hitting a record high.
- The currency is on track to end the year more than 12% stronger against the dollar, supported by improved fiscal performance and inflation containment.
- Johannesburg’s Top-40 Index rose about 0.6%, with thinner trading ahead of year-end holidays.

items.title: Markets in 2025: Gold, goldilocks and the dollar bears
items.author: Marc Jones
items.summary:
- Global markets posted broad gains: stocks up ~$14T in market cap, gold ~70%, dollar down ~10%, EM debt rallying, Bitcoin volatile after peaking near $125k, and Nvidia near a $5T valuation.
- Macro backdrop: expected U.S. rate cuts, rising term premia, and AI-driven spending underpinning EM strength and gold rally.
- Lookahead risks: US midterms/elections, potential Fed leadership changes, ongoing AI uncertainty, with EM bear-market dynamics and term premia as key watchpoints.

items.title: US economic growth likely remained strong in third quarter
items.author: Lucia Mutikani
items.summary: - GDP rose 4.3% at an annualized rate in Q3, topping Q2's 3.8% and economists' 3.3% forecast, though data were delayed by a 43-day shutdown.\n- Consumer spending up 3.5%, led by higher-income households and stock wealth, while tariffs and costs weigh middle- and lower-income groups in a K-shaped recovery.\n- The Fed cut rates 25 bps to 3.50-3.75%; further cuts look unlikely as inflation and labor signals remain unclear, with AI investment boosting capex.

items.title: US business equipment borrowings down more than 4% y/y in November, ELFA says
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- In November, U.S. companies borrowed 4.4% less for equipment investments year over year, with new financing totaling $10.3 billion (seasonally adjusted).
- Activity declined across banks, captives, and independents: banks $4.9B (-1%), captives $2.9B (-9.3%), independents $1.9B (-12.9%).
- ELFA notes healthy financial conditions and says a 75 basis-point cut in the federal funds rate in 2025 could bolster equipment-demand momentum; Confidence Index held at 58.3.

items.title: Driverless future gains momentum with global robotaxi deployments
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Global robotaxi testing and partnerships span Uber/Lyft, Baidu Apollo Go, WeRide, Pony.ai, Zoox, Waymo, Tesla, Mercedes-Benz, Grab and others, with 2025–2026 trials.
- Driverless pilots and limited services are planned in Austin, London, San Francisco, Guangzhou, Singapore, Abu Dhabi, Zurich and more as permits expand.
- The pace signals broad global momentum with fleet ops, safety monitoring and charging to enable commercial autonomous ride-hailing.
